review_blob: Beer Bistro. Seriously, this is in the 99 percentile? Sure its a solid wheat beer, but thats really all it is. Good to style, some standard notes of banana, clove, grass, and honey, but nothing that would make it stand out in its class, or certainly stand out as paired against many beers of similar rating on this site. I was looking for something that would eclipse Dancing Man, and frankly, this doesnt come close. Add to the lack of complexity a pretty weak mouthfeel and not much of a finish. Okay to good, but not great.

Great Taste, 2009. One of the best aromas of the day, with notes of orange, fig, apricot, and bing cherry. On the palate is plenty of funk, and the beer shows its complexity and the craft of the brewer. Notes of dried stone fruit and red wine vinegar, with a finish of vanilla and toasty oak. Not quite as refreshing on a hot day as the other JP beers were, but this was the most complex among them.

Great Taste, 2009. This was pleasant, but I wasnt blown away by the complexity. Having enjoyed One, Two, and Three earlier in the day, I had high hopes for Four. It certainly was refreshing with the brett. It too me drank more like a saison though than a sour ale. Notes of peach, lemon, pineapple, and grass. Nice, but not exceptional compared with other beers that day, or even against the other beers Surly brought.

Pre Great Taste, Maduro, Madison. It had been quite some time since I last had this, and I remember the fall stouts from Bells with much fondness. Id like to see Bells take this in a bourbon barrel direction, as this would lend itself well to this beer. THe nose is not overpowering. The palate is chewy, a bit roasted, with notes of cocoa powder and cream. Finish is chewy and drying. A solid sipper.

Great Taste, 2009. I tried small tastes of 6 of their meads, and for the most part, found them very sweet and not overly complex, although the cinammon vanilla one was fun. This mead and the tupelo honey mead brought the most to the table. The spiceness of the buckwheat plays off well against the sweetness of the body. Notes of vanilla, raw sugar, and apricot add some complexity. Not as good as some of the great Polish meads, but still a solid drink.

Great Taste, 2009. Im not a big fan of the regular Hop Mouth, but I found this to be an improvement. It seems that the combination of the bourbon and the additional ageing time helped round out the hops on this beer, which can seem overpowering and out of balance on fresh Hopmouth. Notes of lemon, caramel, dried cherry and apricot, and grass on the palate. Not as complex as the best bourbon IIPAs and barleywines of the day, but still very good.

Great Taste, 2009. According to the program, aged in a Founders Canadian Breakfast stout barrel. Nice collaboration there. I liked this somewhat less than the Dark Trippel, although I liked the blurring of the lines between barleywine and quad, as this was very heavy on the caramel and dark fruit, but with the characteristic Belgian Quad yeast finish. This was boozy, although not hot. Finish is warming and fruity, with vanilla and oak contributing. Nicely done.

Great Taste, 2009. Im a sucker for well-made saisons, particularly when one is looking for a palate cleanser at a festival. Theres plenty of complexity here, with notes of hay, grass, lemon, and plenty of funkiness from the brett. The finish is bitter for the style, but the hops play well against the sourness. Well made, and perhaps the best saisons of the day.

Great Taste, 2009. In one hand I had Raspberry Eisbock (poured from a small bottle), in another Creme Brulee ice cold, and finally, this one. It reminded me of a more complex version of Bells Cherry Stout, much more oily and viscous. The cherry flavor here is not sweet, but rather plays off against the tar and roasted flavors. Notes of soy, raisin, and dried cherry on the palate.

Great Taste, 2009. I appreciate a beer that stands out against the other big beers of the day. The nose is a great balance of smoke and bourbon, something akin to what one smells in a glass of Lagavuilin. The palate is bacon, raw sugar, and spicy. All that is missing here is a meatiness/chewiness to the beer that you might expect given the nose and the flavor profile. Finish is vanilla and lingering smoke.

Great Taste, 2009. Not as many quality barleywines there this year as in years past. The sweetness here is very much balanced against the 66 IBUs. The malt backbone stands up well against the hops, and Im actually surprised the alcohol level isnt a bit higher. Notes of sour cherry, brown sugar, and a sweet tar-like chewiness. Finishes with mellowed hops and vanilla.

Great Taste, 2009. On a day with plenty of bourbon barrel beers, brett-based sour ales, and everything in between, this actually stood out for its uniqueness. I still cant decide from my notes whether I liked it, as it seems to go a number of different directions. One thing though is that I think it needs some time to round out a bit. Onto the beer, the nose is particularly striking, making it clear that a lot of things are going on here. It reminded me on the nose of one of Firestone Walkers complex, blended beers. On the palate, notes of caramel, butter, dried apricot, pear, leading into darker fruit and burnt toffee. It was a bit hot on the finish, with pronounced vanilla and wood. Interesting, and it would be fun to try it again by itself.

Great Taste, 2009. Im a big fan of Kombucha, and so I was excited to try this. I enjoyed it quite a bit, although I could certainly see why someone would react negatively to it, as a few of my friends did. Lots of lemon and ginger flavors, with orange zest. A floral quality to the nose that was inviting. Finish is palate cleansing, lambic-like.

Great Taste, 2009. Livery put on a strong show once again, and this was one of the highlights. The nectarines really come as a surprise and play off well against the caramel and toffee notes, adding a touch of sweetness. There is plenty of spiceness to this, with nutmeg and cardamom present. It finishes warm, but not hot. Once again, the Livery does not disappoint at GTotM. One of my favorite beers of the day.

Great Taste. Near the end of the festival, when one has the fortitude to hit the high alcohol meads. Notes of cinnamon, nutmeg, toast, apricot, and buckwheat honey. Very viscous, as a good mead should be. Perhaps not quite as complex as Jadwiga, but very good nonetheless.

Great Taste, 2009. If there was a surprise theme of the day, it was the quality of the sour and brett ales. This was one of the highlights in that regard, and rivaled New Glarus version in my mind. Notes of tart cherry and toffee and plum, with other bright stone fruit lending a role. Finish is toasty oak.

Great Taste, 2009. I liked this quite a bit, and I certainly would not have guessed 15%. Impressively made. Notes of brown sugar and sour cherry dominate the palate, with vanilla adding a supporting role, The finish manages to be both sweet and tart. Very warming, but not hot. Perhaps the ultimate cigar beer?

Great Taste, 2009. Flossmoor Station was a bit disappointing this year compared with years past, but this was certainly a highlight. A wonderful palate cleanser from some of the bigger beers that came before it. Notes of orange and vinegar on the palate blend with sour cherry and lemon zest. Lots of funkiness to this one. Nicely done, and a good way to wind down the day in Madison.

Great Taste, 2009. My favorite beer of the day, which is saying quite a bit. Very complex, very rich, and the cherry fruit on the finish comes as a reprieve from all of the wonderful chocolate, coffee, cream flavors. Warming (but not unpleasantly so) bourbon finish with plenty of maple to balance out the cherry. Very well extracted.
beer_name: Americas Bourbon Barrel Hannahs Cherry Imperial Stout

review_blob: Great Taste, 2009. This was particularly creamy, although not as viscous as Barley Johns Triple Oat stout in the cask tent. I was pleased to see this under Town Halls tent, as it was noticeably absent from the cask tent. Notes of cream, toffee, brown sugar, and lightly roasted coffee lead into milk chocolate. Nicely rounded, and it stood out from the other stouts of the day.

Great Taste, 2009. I wasnt as taken with this beer as my fellow raters. I found it a bit too hot and a bit less complex than one would have expected, particularly when juxtaposed with the other great imperial stouts of the day. Notes of dark chocolate, soy, caramel, and cinnamon. The finish is toasty and a tad hot. Altogether a well crafted beer, but lacking the complexity I might have expected given the ratings below.
beer_name: Shoreline Big Bourbon Series Lost Sailor Imperial Stout

review_blob: Great Taste, 2009. This was one of my favorite bourbon barleywines of the day, and it certainly gave Great Danes a run for the money, which is also very good. Strong notes of butterscotch here with more butter and richness on the finish. Caramel, toffee, and vanilla, with dried cherry. Very complex, and the bourbon was not overwhelming. Excellent, and a nice surprise from a relatively unknown brewer.

Great Taste, 2009. Destihl was the surprise of the day, putting on a nice show. This was excellent, and demonstrates that a skilled brewer can come out of a destination like Normal, IL. Notes of cherry, grass, orange and lemon finish with vanilla and oak. I liked the playoff here of sour notes with the hops and the bourbon, playing on the sweet-savory theme. Nicely done.
beer_name: Destihl Saint Dekkera Barrel Reserve Sour: Lenvoy

review_blob: Pre Great Taste, Maduro, 2009. Talk about a beer that lends itself well to bourbon ageing. The creaminess of double cream is exentuated by the barrel ageing, and I think now that double cream contributed more to the complexity of the bourbon-barrel double-cream/expedition, whereas I used to think the Expedition was pulling the weight. Notes of vanilla, oatmeal, raisin, and caramel, with a semi-sweet chocolate and bourbon finish. Nicely done.
beer_name: Bells Special Double Cream Stout - Bourbon Barrel

review_blob: Pre-Great Taste, Glass Nickel. This one seems surprisingly underrated, and perhaps earlier batches were not as well done or complex. I was impressed with this beer, for one, that it hides its alcohol remarkably well. Second, the flavors are well rounded, without too much bourbon, or too much of a hops bite for that matter. Notes of grapefruit, hay, vanilla, and mango on the palate. Well done.
beer_name: Founders Backstage Series # 6: Doom Imperial IPA

review_blob: Pre Great-Taste party and again at Great Taste, 2009. Waited in line for about 45 minutes for this at Glass Nickel. My initial reaction was that this is not all that distinct from Kentucky Breakfast, although perhaps a bit more sweetness comes out here. Im a fan of both Breakfast and Kentucky Breakfast, but Im not sure this one is adding all that much to the lineup. It is very good, but one would need to try all three side by side to unravel the differences in flavor. Notes of chocolate, oat, coffee, vanilla, with a bourbon finish. Well done, but perhaps a bit gimmicky.
beer_name: Founders Backstage Series # 2: CBS (Canadian Breakfast Stout)

review_blob: Great Taste 2009. Note the finest imperial stout of the day, but I could see why people like it. Notes of semi-sweet chocolate, raisin, dark cherry. Fairly creamy, with vanilla and oak undertones, which are more pronounced on the finish. I didnt find it as complex as several other of the Imperial Stouts that day, but this was very good.
beer_name: Free State Owd Macs Imperial Stout

review_blob: Great Taste 2009. This has aged marvelously well, and my first thought was that this was not a doppelbock, but perhaps an old ale. Lots of dark fruit and dried fruit on the aroma and on the palate. It finished incredibly smooth. Nicely done, and good to see it again after a few years hiatus.

Bottle. Pour is exceptionally dark with a dark tan head. Nose is rich coffee oatmeal, leading into oats, chocolate, raisin, vanilla and mocha flavors. Im not sure I pick up the Civet (having only had it once otherwise), but the flavors of the beer are well rounded and complex. It does, however, seem a bit thin, particularly when paired against the great imperial stouts.

Its worth a special trip to try this and to reflect on the differences between the version brewed here and the one back in the States. Im not a big fan of Hop Devil to begin, but this was an enjoyable beer that paired well with the food. One would be hard pressed to tell a difference in the appearance between the two, although I thought on the palate that this came out maltier than the U.S. version, i.e. more caramel with bitter orange than the more hops dominated American version. A nice beer, and a nice respite from all the lagers and pilsners I had been drinking until then.
beer_name: 1516 NZ Victory Hop Devil India Pale Ale

review_blob: I believe this was a different beer than the ratings from last summer, or at least my impression of it was considerably better than others on this site. I sampled all of the beers on tap, and this was by far the best, topping the Hop Devil in my mind. The color is a amber-red, with notes of granny smith apple and cinammon on the nose, leading into a flemish sour ale like palate with sour apple, cherry, and fig flavors, with a finish of pure apple goodness. A very complex cider, one of the best I have enjoyed.

Bottle from Friar Tuck, Savoy. With a name like Hop Stoopid, I expected the hops to dominate everything else. I was pleasantly surprised to find that there was some balance to this beer. It reminded me a bit of Founders Devil Dancer, with its pleasant notes of grass, caramel, and honey, and a finish of pine and grapefruit. Nicely done for the style, and a beer I expect would age rather well.

Bottle. Sampled with the non barrel aged and barrel aged yeti side by side. Certainly more complex than the regular Yeti, although I liked it less than the oak aged. It seemed to me that the espresso had faded a bit, that there was a touch of an old coffee flavor that was less than desirable. Still the pronounced vanilla and caramel flavors with toasted oak made for a pleasant experience.
beer_name: Great Divide Yeti Imperial Stout - Espresso Oak Aged

review_blob: Part of a So Tier sampling party. This was my favorite of the evening. In general Im not overwhelmed by the quality of chocolate stouts (I prefer the coffee stouts), but this was excellent. Appropriately roasted with a desirable bittersweet chocolate bite, blended with notes of soy, caramel, and dutch process cocoa. Nicely done.

Part of a So. Tier sampling party. My sense was that Choklat was a bit better, but I very much enjoyed this as well. The mouthfeel and viscosity was superior to Chocklat, but my sense was that while coffee and chocolate do work well together, they work less well in beer, where the flavors become entangled and detract rather than benefit.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle. Perhaps one of the better IIPAs Ive enjoyed in some time. I expected this to lack much balance and be very hop forward, but I was pleasantly surprised to find a fair amount of caramel, grass, and toasty flavors. The finish, of course, is pure hops. Its a solid take on the style, and one I would return to again.

Thanks to Noah for the bottle. This seemed an appropriate way to commemorate rating number 400. What strikes one most about this now after a few years is the profound nose, with notes of lemongrass, toffee, orange, and vanilla seeping out of the glass. Leading into the palate, one picks up dried cherries and Meyer lemons, with burnt sugar rounding things out. Theres a hint of oxidation here, but this has aged very well.

On draught at Destihl. Pours a dark copper hue with notes of cherry and a nose similar to a good scotch ale. On the palate is less sourness than one might expect, and instead toasted oak (guessing this is spending some time on oak or bourbon), Montmorency cherry, orange zest, cardamom, and a toasty finish. Among the sour ales, it reminded me of Panil Barrique. Im happy to see Destihl breaking new ground, as this was one of several excellent feature beers.

On tap at the Publican, Chicago, January. This was an excellent pairing with the wonderful, peasant styled food of the restaurant. In many ways the beer reminds me more of an old ale than an imperial stout, with dried fruit and spice coming before hops and roasted malts. Sure theres the coffee, the dark roast coffee, and the rich mouthfeel, but theres plenty of prune, toffee, anise, and cardamom. Together its another superbly crafted beer from Struise.

Bottle, Friar Tuck, Savoy. Ive enjoyed this barrel aged and with maple. Its nice to see the standard version in the bottle. This is really an exceptional porter, much better than the standard go-to porter of Fullers, and much more drinkable than the Alpha Klaus, which I also appreciate. The nose is dominated by semi-sweet chocolate with a touch of anise and a surprising note of chamomile that doesnt show up on the palate. Palate is viscous with bittersweet chocolate dominating, added to notes of cardamom and robust molasses. Another great beer at a great price from the good people at Founders.

Bottle, Friar Tuck, Savoy. Finally getting around to rating this beer. Notes of apricot and grass on the nose lead into lemongrass, caramel, pine sol, and gooseberry. The onslaught of hops takes over on the finish. This is good, although I like my IIPAs either more fruit-forward (e.g. the mango/apricot dominance of Dreadnaught) or solid grapefruit/pine (plenty examples here, but West Coast IIPAs come to mind). This caramel notes and the sweetness a the start I find unsettling, although I can appreciate the complexity. This always seemed to me to have the flavor profile of ageing well, but the 4 year old version I had a few months back suggested otherwise. Averys beers in general seem like good candidates for ageing on first impression, and yet they dont seem to stand up to the time in the cellar very well.
beer_name: Avery The Maharaja Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: Bottle. My sense is that this one needs to lay down for 2-3 years, and the flavors seem to need to round out a bit and the hops to fade, allowing the complexity to come out. I say this particularly having rated the beer fresh and now after some time to age, with the aged version the better. Notes of semi-sweet chocolate mesh with oatmeal and cocoa nibs. Tar and mild smoke contribute to the dominant note and acidity of an Ethiopian blend coffee. The mouthfeel and texture of the beer is impressive. Perhaps what is lacking right now will be made up for with more time in the cellar. This beer would have made more sense to me as a Vertical release than a part of the Anniversary series.
beer_name: Stone 20th Anniversary Encore Series: Bitter Chocolate Oatmeal Stout

review_blob: Hopleaf.  I recognize the honey qualifies this as a "mead," but that deScriptor is a bit misleading. This is not like the great Polish meads or other European varieties. This is really a quality beer, and one that must warm up from the cold draft temperature to truly appreciate its complexity.The dried fruit and honey notes are much more prominent when warm, whereas cold is dominated by toffee and caramel. Cold, this reminded me of an exceptionally made Altbier, warm, the notes of honey and some hops appear. The complexity and flavor profile is reminiscent of the Liverys Trippelbock (non BA version). In terms of specific flavors, buckwheat honey, dried fig, demera sugar, candied orange peel, nutmeg, and toast. Very well done.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle from the cellar, about 2 years of age. Ive had this fresh a few times, but this benefits from some ageing time. Notes of toffee and a touch of anise on the nose lead into vanilla, toasted oak, prune, marshmallow, and more anise. Well integrated after a few years, and an enjoyable beer to sip from a snifter. Perhaps its only flaw is that its a touch warm and boozy.

Bottle from Sun Singer in Champaign. Pours a bright yellow hue. Assertive notes of lemon peel on the nose lead into abrasive hops with lemongrass, grapefruit, prickly pear, pineapple, and rosemary on the palate. Finish is palate cleansing. Its well done for its style, although not something I would reach for regularly.

On tap at the Map Room in Chicago. Poured an appropriate dark hue for an Impy Stout, with brown lacing. Nose is chocolate and chicory. To be frank, it is not quite as aromatic as the best imperial stouts, but I believe this was partly due to the coldness of the pour. This would have been better around 60 degrees than the 45-50 range. The sweetness makes me think Imperial Porter would be the more appropriate designation, which I recall having thought when I had their Russian Imperial Stout on tap. I liked this  better, as the dry hops seems to impart more complexity, but the differences between those two beers also seem to be at the margins. I would not have guessed 11.7 for the ABV -- 9.5 to 10 would have been my thought, and so credit to the brewers for their skill. Where this is a touch lacking is in the viscosity and silky texture that come with the best imperial stouts, but the flavors of semi-sweet chocolate (surprisingly not as pronounced as the nose would indicate), currant, dark corn syrup, and charred marshmallow are present. Nicely done.

On tap at Piece. Enjoyed side by side with Moose Knuckle. The copper color of this is exceptional for the style and well done. The nose is grapefruit intermingled with rosemary, and the palate is where these flavors blend with demera sugar and buckwheat honey. Nice finish. A very drinkable IIPA, particularly for the level of alcohol, although not as drinkable and unctuous as the Moose Knuckle.
beer_name: Piece Camel Toe Egyptian Pale Ale

review_blob: Bottle. Enjoyed side by side with Founders Breakfast Stout. Stylistically, this struck me as more similar to some of the east coast stouts. This was noticeably thinner and less unctuous as the breakfast stout, but I respect it for not trying to overdo each component, but rather, to offer a well crafted, well extracted stout.  Flavors of soy, chicory, and a touch of smoke with Sumatran coffee on the finish. Nonetheless, it lacked the body and mouthfeel of what I equate with a stout ranked in the high 3s or low 4s on this site. Well made and a stout I would drink often, just not exceptional for its class.

Provisions Market in St. Louis, multiple tastings at their 100 Brews event. Im a big fan of Flemish sours, and I was pleasantly surprised with the complexity of this one. One expects notes of Montmorency cherry, but one is pleasantly surprised to also find a great combination of oak, Pedro Ximenez sherry, balsamic vinegar, nutmeg, and some brown sugar. Im also suprised by the ABV, as I would have guessed in the 6% range. Very good, the best beer Ive had to date from Haanbryggeriet.

Provisions Market in St. Louis. This was the surprise beer of the day for me at their tasting, and one that I had knew needed to be enjoyed again to appreciate. This strikes me as similar to Old Engine Oil in that it has characteristics of an old ale and a stout together. Whats noticeable here is the blackness of the pour and the thickness of the mouthfeel, which coats the tongue. Notes of molasses and tar combine with sweet vanilla and smoke. Theres a good amount of dark stone fruits here, and the finish is warm and embracing. Great stuff.
